Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content:
I hope that everyone in this channel remembers it was due to the work of Luke that made claiming rewards from ledger possible. The fact that @PTYX decided to steal our idea and steal the credit without contributing a cent to the development is low.

https://twitter.com/Chainzillaio/status/1070729288964554752

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: the term ```interest``` was used and not ```rewards```. other than that... was it stolen?  I think @PTYX  has contributed to this ecosystem.  How much should it be to integrate the ledger claim feature? I'm sure this could be of value to future white label package clients.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: The team uses rewards @actionslacks . @PTYX has contributed to the ecosystem i have no doubt, but who has funded the dev hours to get ledger claim support when ledger themselves did not want to do it? Who has contributed to the dev hours to test and come up with this solution?

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: Whilst i appreciate your input, you have no clue what you are talking about here.

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: I often have no clue. carry on.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: The answers to the questions above just to be clear was me. I paid for the dev hours to come up with a solution and to get ledger to merge in the code (Without this code merged there is no way for PTYX to do a rewards claim). I did it for the community and to hopefully collect a small fee so we can continue to fund more development for Komodo.

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: It is a punch in the guts when someone takes our idea and our hard work and claim it to be their own.

Author: jorian#4555
Content: he just shares the news, what is so wrong about that

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: @hyperDEX i stole your idea. how awful of me to use open source software.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: if you wanted fame, money, or recognition, then you should have closed sourced it. I am not going to twiddle my thumbs and wait months to have a working claim function on a wallet. I also wasn't going to wait months to see the ChainZilla token on the ledger device. I think your behavior is childish, I do hope all those words sink in later when you read them again.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: That's the other issue

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: So there's the fact that this wallet  clearly makes use of our work on the Ledger firmware. But we've done that for the community, anyone is free to use that how they wish. It's kind of uncool to announce you've done it first right before we've made it clear we're about to publically announce our app, but whatever.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: There is another issue however

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: If you decompile magnum wallets JavaScript source code you can clearly see they've ripped code straight from our implementation

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Literally copy/pasted code from https://github.com/atomiclabs/komodo-ledger-reward-claim straight in to their code

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: our project is licensed under MIT, and magnum wallet is closed source

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: they aren't distributing our license or providing attribution

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: people are saying nobody has stolen anything

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: this is literally "theft" in terms of copyright law

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: https://opensource.stackexchange.com/questions/5700/is-using-mit-licensed-code-in-non-open-source-code-considered-stealing

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
```
For all software libraries, copyright law applies, and you must read and follow the license in order to use it legally. For a MIT licensed code library, if you distribute the resulting package, you must also distribute it with a copy of the license including the original copyright notices. Failure to do so is "stealing" or more technically a copyright violation, which you should address.
```

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I hate the idea of copyright and I'm definitely not going to sue anyone over a dispute. But sometime it does genuinely serve to protect the right of software developers, and I kind of just trust other developers to respect that.
